result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 in seawater into chemical fuel, methanol (CH 3 OH), was achieved over CuC-co-doped TiO 2 nanoparticles under UV and natural sunlight.Photocatalysts with different Cu loadings (0, 0.5, 1, 3, 5, and 7 wt) were synthesized by the sol-gel method and were characterized by XRD, SEM, UV-Vis, FTIR, and XPS.Co-doping with C and Cu into TiO 2 remarkably promoted the photocatalytic production of CH 3 OH.This improvement was attributed to lowering of bandgap energy, specific catalytic

energy, specific catalytic effect of Cu for CH 3 OH formation, and the minimization of photo-generated carrier recombination.Co-doped TiO 2 with 3.0 wt Cu was found to be the most active catalyst, giving a maximum methanol yield rate of 577 mol g-cat -1 h -1 under illumination of UV light, which is 5.3-fold higher than the production rate over C-TiO 2 and 7.4 times the amount produced using Degussa P25 TiO 2 .Under natural sunlight, the maximum rate of the photocatalytic production of CH 3 OH using 3.0 wt

of CH 3 OH using 3.0 wt CuC-TiO 2 was found to be 188 mol g-cat -1 h -1 , which is 2.24 times higher than that of C-TiO 2 , whereas, no CH 3 OH was observed for P25.Keywords CO 2 photoreduction .CuC-co-doped TiO 2 .Methanol .Copper .Seawater

reduction of CO 2 and the corresponding CH 3 OH production at a various interval of time using P25-TiO 2 , C-TiO 2 , and 3 wt CuC-TiO 2 in seawater are shown in Fig. 8.The maximum rate of the photocatalytic production of CH 3 OH using 3.0 wt CuC-TiO 2 was found to be 188 mol g-cat -1 h -1 , which is 2.24 times higher than that of C-TiO 2 , whereas no CH 3 OH was observed for P25.Similar to UV results, the current CH 3 OH production yield in seawater under real sunlight is higher than that we previously

2 photocatalysts.The uniform dispersion of the copper clusters on the surface of 3 CuC-TiO 2 is clearly noted.The elemental compositions of the three photocatalysts determined through EDS analysis are presented in Table 1.The EDS analysis confirmed the presence of carbon and copper in CuC-TiO 2 nanoparticles (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary material).Notably, neither C nor Cu was observed in P25. The optical bandgap energy (E g ) values for all samples were measured by using the Tauc plot (Kubelka 1948;Tauc

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

Possible Choices:

analysis systems operating at a base pressure of 4 10 -10 mbar.A dual-anode non-monochromatic Mg-K (1253.6 eV) X-ray source was used to irradiate the sample surface with 13.5 kV and 150 W of X-ray power. The photocatalytic reduction experiments were carried out in a homemade batch annular reactor.The reactor was made up of Pyrex glass and was coupled to the CO 2 cylinder with a firmly closed tube.Liquid samples were taken out at regular interval of time using a syringe, which is linked to the reactor

a standard reference catalyst for comparison. A Shimadzu X-ray diffractometer (XRD-6000) equipped with Cu K radiation operating at 30 mA and 40 kV was used to determine the crystallinity of the catalysts.X-ray data were collected over the 2 range of 20-70at a scan rate of 1.0min -1 .The optical properties of the photocatalysts were evaluated by a Shimadzu, PharmaSpec UV-1700 Spectrophotometer.A JSM-7600F, JEOL (USA) Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) attached with Energy-Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopic unit

into the seawater.The carbonate reacts with CO 2 to form bicarbonate, which leads to a further uptake of CO 2 and a decline of the CO 3 2-concentration in the ocean.In this case, the production of CH 3 OH is from the reduction of not only CO 2 but also all the carbonate species.So, the yield of CH 3 OH from seawater medium is much more than that of freshwater.
